summary: The Good Friday Agreement, signed in 1998, ended most of the violence in Northern Ireland's long conflict, known as the Troubles. It created a new way for Northern Ireland to govern itself, with power shared between different groups. The agreement also improved relations between Northern Ireland, Ireland, and the United Kingdom. It was approved by voters in Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland in referendums. Most political parties supported it, but the Democratic Unionist Party (DUP) did not.
title: Good Friday Agreement
